courses.title: Elementary Statistics for Applications
courses.description: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation.
courses.notes: Credit excluded with STAT_V 203, BIOL_V 300, BUSI_V 291, COMM_V 191, 291, ECON_V 325, 327, EPSE_V 482, FRST_V 231, GEOG_V 374, KIN_V 206, 371, LFS_V 252, POLI_V 380, PSYC_V 218, 278, SOCI_V 328

courses.title: Statistical Inference for Data Science
courses.description: Classical and simulation-based techniques for estimation and hypothesis testing, including inference for means and proportions. Emphasis on case studies and real data sets, as well as reproducible and transparent workflows when writing computer scripts for analysis and reports.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit.
courses.notes: Credit excluded with ECON_V 325, 327, PSYC_V 366, COMM_V 290

courses.title: Intermediate Statistics for Applications
courses.description: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing.

courses.title: Statistical Modelling for Data Science
courses.description: Data analysis using statistical models and algorithms (e.g., linear and logistic regression, peeking, bandit, and variable selection algorithms) in case studies from different disciplines. Generative versus out-of-sample predictive models. Reproducible and transparent workflows for computer scripts and reports.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability
courses.description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems.

courses.title: Finding Relationships in Data
courses.description: Modelling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables: multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data. Finding low-dimensional structure: principal components analysis. Cluster analysis.

courses.title: Methods for Statistical Learning
courses.description: Flexible, data-adaptive methods for regression and classification models; regression smoothers; penalty methods; assessing accuracy of prediction; model selection; robustness; classification and regression trees; nearest-neighbour methods; neural networks; model averaging and ensembles; computational time and visualization for large data sets.

courses.title: Differential Calculus with Applications
courses.description: Derivatives of elementary functions. Applications and modelling: graphing, optimization.

courses.title: Integral Calculus with Applications
courses.description: The definite integral, integration techniques, applications, modelling, infinite series.

courses.title: Calculus III
courses.description: Analytic geometry in 2 and 3 dimensions, partial and directional derivatives, chain rule, maxima and minima, second derivative test, Lagrange multipliers, multiple integrals with applications.
courses.notes: Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/faculty-science/bachelor-science/credit-exclusion-lists

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Computing
courses.description: Introduction to mathematical software and numerical methods. Numbers, arrays, functions, vectorization and iteration. Sequences and series, root finding, numerical integration, numerical methods for differential equations, systems of linear equations, mathematical graphics.

courses.title: Elementary Differential Equations I
courses.description: First-order equations; linear equations; linear systems; Laplace transforms; numerical methods; trajectory analysis of plane nonlinear systems. Applications of these topics will be emphasized.

courses.title: Matrix Algebra
courses.description: Systems of linear equations, operations on matrices, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of symmetric matrices.
courses.notes: This course is intended for first and second year students. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/faculty-science/bachelor-science/credit-exclusion-lists. Equivalency: MATH_V 111

courses.title: Introduction to Data Science
courses.description: Use of data science tools to summarize, visualize, and analyze data. Sensible workflows and clear interpretations are emphasized.

courses.title: Navigating Data: Acquisition, Exploration and Management
courses.description: Acquiring data through web scraping and generating synthetic data via simulations. Sampling and experimental designs. Reporting and visualizing data and data quality. Data privacy and ownership. Emphasis on case studies and real data sets.

courses.title: Discrete Mathematics for Data Science
courses.description: Boolean algebra and logical inference, proof techniques, sets, relations and functions, regular expressions, and data filtering.

courses.title: Data Structures for Data Science
courses.description: Object-oriented programming. Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures especially relevant to data science. Algorithm analysis methods, basic data structures, graphs and graph algorithms.

courses.title: Reproducible and Trustworthy Workflows for Data Science
courses.description: Data science methods to automate the running and testing of code and analytic reports, manage data analysis software dependencies, package and deploy software for data analysis, and collaborate with others using version control.

courses.title: Visualization for Data Science
courses.description: Analysis, design, and implementation of static and interactive visual representations; visualization literacy; data communication; exploratory Data Analysis; application of theoretical principles to visualization development.

courses.title: Fairness, Accountability, Transparency and Ethics (FATE) in Data Science
courses.description: Ethical application of data science and machine learning algorithms. Application of ethical theories in real-world case studies. Data ownership, collection, and validity. Algorithm auditing, fairness and transparency. Reducing unfairness in algorithms. Deployment of predictive models and dissemination of results.

courses.title: Introduction to Systematic Program Design
courses.description: Computation as a tool for systematic problem solving in non-computer-science disciplines. Introductory programming skills. No programming experience expected.
courses.notes: Not for credit for students who have credit for, or exemption from, or are concurrently taking CPSC 110 or APSC 160.

courses.title: Systematic Program Design
courses.description: Fundamental computation and program structures. Continuing systematic program design from CPSC 103.

courses.title: Computation, Programs, and Programming
courses.description: Fundamental program and computation structures. Introductory programming skills. Computation as a tool for information processing, simulation and modelling, and interacting with the world.

courses.title: Models of Computation
courses.description: Physical and mathematical structures of computation. Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution.

courses.title: Programming, Problem Solving, and Algorithms
courses.description: Analysis of increasingly complex algorithmic problems, using a modern programming language and a variety of approaches. Problem decomposition and abstraction guide explorations of topics from applied algorithms, for example Voronoi Diagrams, Markov Chains, Bin Packing, and Graph Search.
courses.notes: Not for students with credit for, or currently enrolled in, CPSC 210 or CPEN 221.

courses.title: Software Construction
courses.description: Design, development, and analysis of robust software components. Topics such as software design, computational models, data structures, debugging, and testing.

courses.title: Applied Machine Learning
courses.description: Application of machine learning tools, with an emphasis on solving practical problems. Data cleaning, feature extraction, supervised and unsupervised machine learning, reproducible workflows, and communicating results.

courses.title: Machine Learning and Data Mining
courses.description: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence.

courses.title: Statistical Methods
courses.description: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models.
courses.notes: Not for credit towards a B.Sc. Credit excluded with STAT_V 200, BIOL_V 300, BUSI_V 291, COMM_V 191, 291, ECON_V 325, 327, EPSE_V 482, FRST_V 231, GEOG_V 374, KIN_V 206, 371, LFS_V 252, POLI_V 380, PSYC_V 218, 278, SOCI_V 328

courses.title: Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
courses.description: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency.

courses.title: Mathematical Proof
courses.description: Sets and functions; induction; cardinality; properties of the real numbers; sequences, series, and limits. Logic, structure, style, and clarity of proofs emphasized throughout.

programs.name: All Courses
programs.requirements_html:
Course Information

The course map presents all DSCI, STAT, MATH, and CPSC courses along with prerequisite/corequisite connections. Hover over a course to view the course description, a complete list of prerequisites/corequisites, credit exclusions and notes. Select programs and streams in the menu above.

This course mapper was created by Siddarth Chilukuri, based on the original course map by Patrick Walls, Karen Zhou, and Wuyang Li.


This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Note: The course map on the right represents only a subset of the requirements needed to complete the degree. Please refer to the table below or the UBC Academic Calendar for complete degree requirements.

Major in Data Science - Specialization Requirements

programs.name: Minor in Data Science
programs.requirements_html:
Note: The course map on the right represents only a subset of the requirements needed to complete the degree. Please refer to the information below or the UBC Academic Calendar for complete degree requirements.

Minor in Data Science - Requirements

Lower-Level Requirements

  • Data Science: 3 credits of DSCI_V 100.
  • Statistical Inference: 3 credits of STAT_V 201.
  • Pre-requisites for required upper-level courses
  • Programming: 6 credits given by the prerequisites for CPSC_V 330. For most non-CS majors, we recommend CPSC_V 103 followed by CPSC_V 203.
  • Math: 3 credits given by the prerequisites for STAT_V 301.

Upper-Level Requirements

18 credits selected as follows:

  • STAT_V 301
  • CPSC_V 330
  • One of DSCI_V 430, CPSC_V 430
  • Three of the following five options:
    • DSCI_V 310
    • DSCI_V 320
    • CPSC_V 416
    • One of CPSC_V 368, CPSC_V 304, COMM_V 437
    • One of COMM_V 335, COMM_V 365, COMM_V 414, COMM_V 415, COMM_V 475, CPSC_V 322, CPSC_V 340, CPSC_V 406, CPSC_V 447, ECON_V 398, ECON_V 425, EOSC_V 440, EOSC_V 410, EOSC_V 354, INFO_V 419, LING_V 342, MATH_V 441, MATH_V 442, MICB_V 405, MICB_V 425, NSCI_V 303, PHYS_V 410, PSYC_V 359, STAT_V 406, STAT_V 447B, STAT_V 450
